In my experience, success in destabilization hinges not on the quality of the deepfake itself, but on the precision with which it is delivered to the right audience. You see, people are not a monolith; they are fragmented, emotional, and driven by fear, identity, and tribal loyalties. That is where the real power lies.

First, I begin by mapping the information ecosystem of the target population. Social media platforms, forums, chat groups, and even local news outlets are all part of the terrain. I use open-source intelligence (OSINT) to identify which groups are already polarized, which are vulnerable to distrust, and which have the loudest voices that can amplify the message.

For example, in a country with a strong anti-immigrant sentiment, I might craft a deepfake of a political leader making a callous remark about a minority group. I ensure the video is distributed through far-right influencers, encrypted messaging apps, and local radio stations that already cater to that demographic. The key is to make the deepfake feel like it’s coming from within their own community—something familiar, not foreign.

In urban centers with high youth unemployment, I might focus on economic grievances. A deepfake of a government official admitting to embezzling funds or sabotaging job programs could be seeded among students and young workers, shared through TikTok or WhatsApp. It doesn’t need to be perfect—just believable enough to spark outrage.

I also exploit pre-existing narratives. If a community is already suspicious of a particular political party or ethnic group, I create content that reinforces those suspicions. The human mind is wired to accept information that confirms what it already believes. That’s why I always tailor the emotional tone—fear, anger, hope, or even humor—depending on what will resonate most with the group.

I often use micro-targeting tools and bot networks to push the content at scale, ensuring it reaches the right people at the right time. Timing is everything. Launch a deepfake just before an election, during a protest, or in the wake of a natural disaster, and the impact is magnified tenfold.

In short, I don’t just create deepfakes—I curate experiences. I become a whisper in the ear of the already discontent, a spark in the dry grass of public opinion. The more I understand the psychology of my audience, the more effective I become.
